bestBHT.bht: Ananias was regarded as the true high priest, even by the tribune, despite his bad character. The charge against Paul for vehemently abusing the high priest reflected the expectation of respect for the office. Hypocrites tend to focus on others' faults while turning a blind eye to their own. Reviling one in authority, such as the high priest, was against the law of Moses. Nevertheless, even though the priesthood had changed with Jesus Christ as the ultimate High Priest, the reproach against Paul emphasized the solemnity attached to the position.

Henry Alford: 4.] Hence we see, that not only by the Jews, but by the tribune, who was present, Ananias was regarded as the veritable high priest.
Albert Barnes: Dost thou reproach or abuse the high priest of God?"
It is remarkable that they, who knew that he was not the high priest, should have offered this language.
He was, however, in the place of the high priest, and they might have pretended that respect was due to the office.
Marvin Vincent: Revilest [λοιδορεις] . The word signifies vehement abuse, scolding, berating.
John Calvin: For why do they not rather blame Ananias, when they saw that he had quite forgotten all modesty, and that he brake out into violence and stripes after a barbarous manner? for even this did turn to the reproach of them all.
But this is a solemn [marked] thing among hypocrites, they look narrowly into other men’s faults and wink at their own.

So fareth it at this day in Popery, the more liberty that impure clergy doth grant to itself, and the more carelessly it waxeth wanton, and polluteth the whole world with the sins which flow thence, the more straitly do they rule and stay the tongues of the people.
Philip Schaff: It was and St. Paul knew it well contrary to the law of Moses (see Exodus 22:28, subsequently quoted by him) to revile one placed in a position of authority."
...to revile one placed in a position of authority, such as the high priest, or any one sitting as president of the Sanhedrim council, 'the father of the house of judgment,' as the Talmud calls him.
Archibald T. Robertson: As God's representative in spite of his bad character.
Here was a charge of irreverence, to say the least.
John Gill: The aggravation of which was not only that the person reviled was a priest, an high priest, but an high priest of God."
Though this could not have been proved, for there was now no high priest of God but Jesus Christ."
The priesthood was changed and abrogated, and there were no more high priests among men of God's appointing and approving.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, we see that Ananias is regarded as the veritable high priest, not only by the Jews but also by the tribune. The charge against Paul of vehemently abusing the high priest reveals the expectation of respect for the office, regardless of Ananias's bad character. It is notable that even those who knew that Ananias was not the high priest used this language. While reviling one in authority was contrary to the law of Moses, it seems that hypocrites often scrutinize others while ignoring their own faults. The reproach against Paul for reviling the high priest reflects the solemnity attached to the position, even though the priesthood had been changed and abrogated with Jesus Christ becoming the ultimate High Priest.

Ananias was regarded as the true high priest, even by the tribune, despite his bad character. The charge against Paul for vehemently abusing the high priest reflected the expectation of respect for the office. Hypocrites tend to focus on others' faults while turning a blind eye to their own. Reviling one in authority, such as the high priest, was against the law of Moses. Nevertheless, even though the priesthood had changed with Jesus Christ as the ultimate High Priest, the reproach against Paul emphasized the solemnity attached to the position.

Ananias was considered the true high priest, not only by the Jews but also by the tribune. Despite his bad character, there was an expectation of respect for the office, as reviling someone in authority was against the law. Hypocrites tend to focus on others' faults while ignoring their own. Even though the priesthood had changed with Jesus Christ as the ultimate High Priest, the reproach against Paul highlighted the significance of the position.

Ananias, although having a bad character, was regarded as the true high priest by both the Jews and the tribune. The charge against Paul for vehemently abusing the high priest emphasizes the importance of respecting the office. Reviling one in authority, such as the high priest, went against the law of Moses. However, hypocrites tend to nitpick at others' faults while turning a blind eye to their own. Despite the change in priesthood with Jesus Christ as the ultimate High Priest, the reproach against Paul underscored the solemnity attached to the position.

Ananias, despite his bad character, was considered the true high priest by both the Jews and the tribune. The charge against Paul for vehemently abusing the high priest highlights the necessity of respecting the office. Reviling one in authority, like the high priest, was against the law of Moses. Nevertheless, hypocrites tend to fixate on others' faults while ignoring their own. Despite the change in priesthood with Jesus Christ as the ultimate High Priest, the reproach against Paul underscores the significance of the position.
